data.title: Jonas Brothers Trademarks
data.meta_description: Consisting of Joseph Jonas (Joe Jonas), Paul Kevin Jonas (Kevin Jonas), and Nicholas Jonas (Nick Jonas), the Jonas Brothers are an American pop-rock band that
data.text:
Consisting of Joseph Jonas (Joe Jonas), Paul Kevin Jonas (Kevin Jonas), and Nicholas Jonas (Nick Jonas), the Jonas Brothers are an American pop-rock band that enjoyed extreme popularity in the 2000s. The band’s style was known to be catchy and upbeat.

The family hails from Wyckoff, New Jersey originally. Kevin Jonas was born in New Jersey, but Nick and Joe were born in Texas and Arizona. They were raised in a Christian home as their father was a preacher. After being diagnosed very young, Nick has been an ardent supporter of diabetes awareness. But that didn’t stop his noted flair for singing, and he began working on Broadway and as a solo performer before being signed by Columbia. Nick’s interest in singing led to him writing a Christmas song alongside his father in 2002.

Their acting debut came as part of the Disney Channel hit show ‘Hannah Montana’. After signing Nick, Colombia records would also sign Kevin and Joe. From 2005 they performed as a trio. Nick Jonas is the lead vocalist and plays rhythm guitar, drum and piano. Kevin Jonas plays the piano and is responsible for backing vocals, while Joe Jonas plays the keyboard and percussions and is a vocalist. Several successful collaborations took place with Miley Cyrus (as Hannah Montana and herself) between 2005 and 2008. They also appeared alongside her for her ‘Best of Both worlds’ tour.

The trio started strong, performing opening acts on tour for Kelly Clarkson and the Backstreet Boys in 2005. In 2006 they ranked 91 on the Billboard with their debut ‘It’s About Time. Initially, they performed under the name ‘Sons Of Jonas’ though this would later become ‘The Jonas Brothers’. After being dropped by Columbia Records in 2007, they were signed by Hollywood Records – a Disney-owned label.

In addition to performances, they also made several TV appearances, including starring as a group of spies in a hit TV series titled ”J.O.N.A.S.” later in 2007, solidifying their popularity among teenagers. Around this time, they also featured in a reality TV show called ‘Jonas Brothers: Living the dream,’ which portrayed their journey on the road. Around 9 million people tuned in to watch the movie, and it also featured the Jonas Brothers’ next single – ‘Burnin’ Up .’ Their presence was further heightened when they featured in Camp Rock alongside big Disney stars such as Demi Lovato and Meaghen Martin Tees.

The Jonas Brothers famously collaborated with Taylor Swift in 2008 on her song ‘Should’ve Said No.’ They would tour and release a fourth studio album ‘Lines Vines and Trying Times’ in 2009. The album would go platinum and become their second chart hit.

As of 2013, the brothers had sold over 17 million albums. Despite reaching great heights, the brothers decided to part ways. In March of 2019, they came back with ‘Sucker.’ the song became the 34th song to ever debut at number one on the Billboard hot 100 and became the first number-one single of the Jonas Brothers. Their fifth studio album, ‘Happiness Begins’ topped the US billboard 200. The brothers are currently touring the U.S.A. and Mexico.

The Jonas Brothers also have an excellent track record for philanthropy. The brothers earned approximately 12 million in 2007 and donated a whopping 10% of this to the Change For the Children Foundation. This foundation, set up by the brothers, donates to key foundations such as Nothing but Nets, the American Diabetes Foundation, and Summer Stars Camp for the performing arts. Nick Jonas also used his fame to testify in the US senate to promote additional funding for the disease. As recently as August 2021, the Jonas Brothers partnered with Feeding America to promote donations to the organization by hosting a competition for a fan to be selected to dine with the brothers at an LA restaurant.

Popular Jonas Brothers trademarks

Trademark registration allows you to protect your intellectual property, which can be worth more than physical property. The Jonas Brothers have a substantial amount of intellectual property to protect. The Jonas Brothers have a small collection of trademarks covering a variety of uses. Jonas Brothers Properties LLC registered all trademarks listed here.

Jonas Brothers

The most crucial trademark on this list is the Jonas Brothers’ name, potentially worth several million. The trademark for the name ‘‘Jonas Brothers’’ is a standard character mark covering several categories. The trademark application was first filed in 2008, following its first use in 2007. The trademark filing covers:

All-purpose rucksacks, sports bags, athletic bags, and more

Beach bags and wallets

Notepads, pens, and other stationery items

Decals, postcards, and small decorations

Posters, stickers, bumper stickers, calendars, photographs

Sound recordings featuring music; video recordings featuring music; downloadable webcasts featuring music and/or information about a musical artist or artists; downloadable podcasts featuring music and/or information about a musical artist or artists; downloadable sound recordings featuring music; downloadable video recordings featuring music, downloadable ring tones for mobile phones

Entertainment services include dramatic performances and live performances

Fanclubs and gatherings

Musical videos and photography services

Jewelry

Related: Can you trademark a band name?

JB logo

The crest logo consists of a shield, and the interlocked letters JB inside has been used since 2008. The logo is most often seen on merchandise, marketing materials, and Fanclub material. The trademark filing applies to:

Clothing including tops, headwear, wristbands, and pullovers

Merchandise such as posters, stickers, souvenirs, and photobooks

Notebooks and writing diaries

Decorative decals

Stationary such as pens, pencils, and other writing materials

Team Jonas

You’ll most often see ‘Team Jonas’ used to refer to fans of the Jonas Brothers; it is also the name of their official fan clubs and is seen on their website as you purchase any merchandise. It was first used in e-commerce in 2008, and the trademark applies to several categories, including:

Entertainment services, including providing non-downloadable music and video recordings via computer networks

Providing information about entertainment services

Websites featuring performances

Podcasts

Fan club services

Clothing, namely, tops

Posters, stickers, photographs, and poster books

The J-Sisters

The Jonas Brothers have all married. The first of the trio to marry was Kevin Jonas, who married Danielle Deleasa in 2009. They have kept a low profile since, but his brothers Nick and Joe married women who were equally famous in their own right – with Nick and Joe choosing Priyanka Chopra and Sophie Turner, respectively.

Nevertheless, the trio of women is incredibly close, and on a 2018 trip, the moniker ‘The J-Sisters’ was born. Initially thought to be a joke, the name has stuck, and they applied to register the wordmark in the following categories:

Calendars, photographs, posters, stickers, bumper stickers

Tote bags

Bottoms as clothing, headwear, sweatshirts, T-shirts, tops as clothing

Wrapping up

The Jonas Brothers are an iconic band that shot to fame during the 2000s, enjoying an immense network during these years. As we’ve already seen, intellectual property can be worth more than physical property, with some famous lawsuits running into the billions. The Jonas Brothers have registered several key trademarks with the USPTO to protect this net worth. As a trademark owner, you have crucial legal protections. The Jonas Brothers don’t have many trademarks but are submitting new applications as recently as 2019.
